Award.AwardTitle: EAGER:MAKER: Piloting a BioDesign Maker Space and Curriculum for K-12 STEM Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers from the Rhode Island School of Design will create a BioDesign Maker Space, providing an immersive environment for K-12 students and other learners to engage in hands-on design projects that cultivate a working knowledge of biology and natural systems. The space will leverage strategies from biophilic design, including features and patterns observed in the natural world shown to improve student focus, productivity and wellbeing. A BioDesign curriculum, developed for use in the space, will explore the use of ecosystem services to design solutions to urban issues such as air and water pollution and food security. Students from area public schools will receive the cumulative benefits of learning in a biophilic space and an approach to STEM learning that emphasizes practical, inquiry-based, design and design thinking methods.

The intellectual merit of this initiative is in its bio-centric approach to the design and construction of learning, living and work environments, leading to improvements in human and environmental health. Through new perspectives on the presence of nature in human spaces, and the power of studio/Makerspace pedagogy, the proposed effort introduces an innovative approach to STEM education that identifies the human-nature connection as integral to engaging students in STEM fields, and preparing them to meet social and environmental challenges. A catalog of BioDesign Maker Space strategies, as well as curriculum modules, will be widely disseminated.

This project is a part of NSF's Maker Dear Colleague Letter (DCL) portfolio (NSF 15-086), a collaborative investment of Directorates for Computer & Information Science & Engineering (CISE), Education and Human Resources (EHR) and Engineering (ENG).

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this study, faculty, staff and student researchers from the Rhode Island School of Design created a BioDesign Makerspace, providing an immersive environment and curriculum for K-12 students and other learners to engage in hands-on design projects that cultivate a working knowledge of biology and natural systems. 

The space was designed by a RISD Interior Architecture studio class using principles from biophilic design, incorporating features and patterns from the natural world shown to improve focus, productivity and wellbeing.  The design was implemented using sustainable materials and practices during the summer of 2018 in a space at the Edna W. Lawrence Nature Lab.

Concurrently, Master's degree students in RISD's Teaching + Learning in Art + Design program worked with a staff scientist to create a biodesign curriculum tailored to meet Next Generation Science Standards as well as National Core Visual Art standards.  The curriculum, which focused on biomimicry, biomaterials and living systems, was taught to a cohort of tenth grade students from the nearby Metropolitan Regional Career and Technical Center (MET) school during the fall, then revised for a second cohort of tenth graders from the MET in the spring of 2019.

To answer the question: How does a nature-rich, life-science curriculum, taught through an art and design pedagogy in a biodesign makerspace, appear to impact student engagement in and attitudes toward science content, an external evaluator collected quantitative data through formative and summative surveys and real-time or recorded observations of student activity during class in multiple categories of behavioral engagement.  Qualitative data was obtained from group interviews, supplemented by student-teacher observations.

Quantitative results demonstrated positive increases in the means for engagement, attitudes toward science and attitudes toward art, shifts worth noting when interpreted alongside qualitative data. Moreover, students did demonstrate performance gains on questions pertaining to science content. Increases in content performance from the first semester to the second suggested that with changes in other variables, such as more frequent or longer classes, there is the potential for students to show marked improvement in their understandings of STEM concepts when applying an art and design-based curriculum.

Group interviews indicated that students did in fact internalize aspects of the life science content, as well as changes in behavior grounded in what they had studied in the program. Many focused on a shift in their relationship to environmental awareness and the use of non-degradable plastics, a focus of the biomaterials unit in the program. They talked about design inspiration from nature as well as the need to protect biodiversity for continued exemplars of how nature operates with limited resources, in an interconnected system that promotes rather than degrades opportunities for other life.  Whereas statistical analysis suggested no significant shifts in student attitudes toward nature or sense of personal agency from the beginning to the end of the program, in conversation, students were clear that this program had an impact on their lives outside of the school environment. The classroom itself also had an impact on student social emotional learning, as they mentioned feeling both calm and alert, and enthusiastic about learning in this specific makerspace.

A website detailing all aspects of the project, design strategies, and our novel biodesign curriculum linked to science and art standards and specific learning criteria can be accessed at https://biomaker.risd.edu.
